name: Velvet Sundown
description: Velvet Sundown is a social multiplayer role-playing game, taking place on a luxury yacht cruising the waters of a fictitious Caribbean state of Balbonia. Embark on a journey full of conspiracies, trickery and secrets where you can never tell a friend from foe.
minimum_requirements: OS: 7 DirectX: Version 10 Network: Broadband Internet connection
recommended_requirements: Network: Broadband Internet connection Sound Card: any

reviews.review_text: This game has the seed of a potentially good idea (online auto-moderated salon-style LARP - never mind that 'online' and 'LA*' are contradictory). However, the execution on that idea is irredeemably flawed. There are three major things lacking: - game size: the free instances are typically limited to 5-6 players, and zero NPCs; it looks like premium scenarios are the same scenarios, with roughly doubled instance sizes. The available scenarios all feel like they would start to get interesting at around 20 players - environmental interaction: Every player starts the game with 2-5 items (which are always the same items in a given scenario, though the character/item match does get shuffled). There are not any other items in the game. There is a big yacht to walk around on, but there's never any reason to. Games tend to devolve quickly into everyone standing around in the same conversation, at which point the setting might as well be a stopped elevator. - depth of plot: Since everything that exists or can exist within the instance starts out in the hands of a small group of people, and nothing happens in the environment, the possible interactions within a scene are usually exhausted inside of 5 minutes. This makes the remaining 25 minutes until the scene actually *ends* (always by the clock running out) quite tedious.  There are also small but crucial mistakes, such as the murder mystery scenario always giving the same piece of evidence to the killer. Figure out what that is, and the mystery becomes really simple: each player has one piece of evidence, so whoever has that one, or refuses to share what they have, must be the killer.

This game. Only 40 hours wasted and hoo boy, y'all are in for a treat. There's about three kinds of people who play this. RPers, trolls and staring contest champions.  RPers: These are the people who take the game seriously and play the game how the developers intended it to be played. You're on a boat, with a bunch of strangers, and you've gotta outwit them to survive. Playing with this type of player is fun and (on occasion) rather intense.  Trolls: These... these players... Hoo boy. Trolls are everywhere, ♥♥♥♥♥, youtube and apparently also in the world's most unplayed and half decent game. They generally walk about, throwing their objectives overboard and going completely nuts. They can be categorized into 2 groups: Serious trolls, and spammers. The serious trolls are actually pretty funny. You get some who will even troll as the character, bringing a crude humor to the game. The spammers will simply talk nonsense. Literally nonse-2o3u9508u4qg5uio4wqhy7tqw3po4itwhovgif4ahmbqiyonh5syegha8oe5u7ty3h8rangkjnz.  ... excuse me...  Staring Contest Champs: 0_0 <-- Don't look at them. Just.. don't risk it.
Voices were removed, no thanks.

After reading a bunch of reviews for this game, i wanted to cleat things up. The free part of this game includes the tutorial and one free scenerio. The scenerio changes every few days. To access the other scenarios, you have to buy the premium, which is less than $10. Currently, the text to speech feature is back in for everyone. You usually can't go wrong with free, and this game gives a decent amount of replayabilty since the free scenario changes, it offers variety also with other players and having a different role in the scenario.  You wont ever get the same playthrough twice, since evryone will act different with Trust and roles and whatnot.  I can definetly say i enjoy playing it and I usually wind up laughing a lot too, so thats a plus.
F2P =/= 1 scenario. Get this through your thick heads you devs! Either charge completely, offer more free content, or don't charge at all.

I really enjoyed this game. I like the premise and I think it's a lot of fun. I wish they weeded out the people who don't take it seriously. When everyone is in character and playing along, this game feels like it's flashing before your eyes. However, when people are just being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, it drags on with the pain of knowing that you might not even complete any of your goals in the end. When people get into it, this is a lot of fun! I wish they had an option to play matches with friends only, or something.

The idea behind this game is a good one. It's got a unique concept not unlike a murder mystery party. Each player assumes the role of a different character - each with their own background story, motives and goals. You enter a scenario not knowing exactly how it will play out. You are encouraged to interact with the other players to discover the mystery .  I give this game a Recommended simply because I believe in the potential that it has. And with enough feedback, the developers can turn this into a really fun experience. I have enjoyed each scenario I have played regardless of the problems the game faces. However, take note of the issues I mention below before purchasing anything.   To see some gameplay and some of the issues I have mention in action - check out the below video:   Velvet Sundown Gameplay Video   Unfortunately, the game needs work before it can reach its full potential. Currently the game suffers from many problems, but none that can't be fixed in future versions.   There is a definite problem with AFK users that cause many paths in the story to never be completed.   The game sort of throws you in without doing much explaining which leaves many first time players confused. So then they spend their time asking 'What am I supposed to do?' instead of roleplaying. A more detailed tutorial would be helpful.
So hilarious, just ♥♥♥♥ing around with the text-to-speech trolling. Made my day.

Cool concept, too bad it requires people who take their roles seriously. Also the game's mechanics are not adequate as conversation and agreeableness within any given game and group of players is all up to chance. Some people cannot be reasoned with, and not everybody spawns with a taser.

To be honest, the story's neat, but what everyone REALLY wanted to play this game was for the text-to-speech. Now that it's bugged out, or removed, nobody cares about it anymore until another game like this can whip out text-to-speech for cheap popularity.

The Good: Game idea - Great combination of old school text adventure mixed with dinner party 'murder mystery' Cluedo.  The Bad: You need to wait in the lobby for 5 players to arrive before the game will start.  The Ugly: Game would be great when playing with friends who know how to behave and want to have fun. However, you are playing with strangers so expect vulgar language, abuse, impatience, trolls and all the wonders of annonymous online 'roleplay'.  Summary: Definitely give it a go if you have a group of friends to share the fun. It is a great mind game. If flying solo, best to give it a miss.

Velvet Sundown Review  Seeming as there isn’t many informative reviews I figured I would give it a try.  Velvet Sundown, a unique role-playing experience. Join a new game as one of many randomly selected characters, each with their own unique backstory and set of missions to complete. Interact with other players in open chat as you attempt to solve your missions and complete the game. Each game session is designed to last about 45 minutes, and millions of game possibilities exist, making each game truly unique.  I personally found this game to be pretty fun and well thought out, you don’t find many games quite like this. Even though there may sometimes be some annoying players who go afk or players who don’t actually role play, it is still a really good experience that everyone should give it a try. Because it is free you might as well take a look into it and if you really enjoy it, you can pay for a premium version which allows you to play a new scenario called “Story of Fathers and Sons”.  Overall I recommend it and that everyone should give it a try.

This Game is Velvet Sundown.  It is a Rpg which has no killing, not much free stuff (only one scernio a week for non payers).  In this Game you play as a person onboard a luxery cruise ship. You have objectives which you need to complete. (ex. Get parents for a orphan child) By chatting to the characters on the ship. This wouldn't be a problem if their were NPCS instead they are online people. And the objective is to chat to other people and get stuff. Some people help you, others don't; and some just use the Game for sex jokes. This game could be really but the community out there uses it to tell sex jokes, troll other people, curse, use bad grammer and make fun of the game.   This Game has potential.  But the community ruins it.  If you like people cursing at you, trolling at you, and sex joking at you than this is for you. However, Do not put this game to shame. Their are some lovely people who you can play with online. Those people are creative with their objectives, don't spam curses, or sex joke. Their interacte with you and make it fun.  Like i said before This Game has potential  So don't let it ruin your fun  5.5 out of 10

If you're looking for a mystery to solve and love the idea of working with real players with real engagement don't get this game. If you have genuine intelligence and think you'll be getting together with like minded individuals, capable of putting together evidence and figuring out alibi's don't get this game. If you think that randy, sad and socially-inadept and deprived individuals are going to give up trying to hit on the female AI to help you actually enjoy this game, don't get this game.   Sorry guys, but this is full of 10-15 year olds asking any female AI to suck various parts of their anatomy, whilst holding back evidence in place of repeating 'f*ck you' and trolling. And this will last for 25 minutes... massive time waster full of people who couldn't understand how to use second-life.   But, I think it's only fair I make a suggestion for improvement rather than waste time ranting. Get a report system in place, get a banning system in place and make use of it. Try to sort your target player wheat from the chaff. Until that's done, I don't think anybody looking to actually play a murder mystery, or looking for what this game claims to be, should bother getting it. It's inundated with trolls and people who genuinely are too daft to play.

If this made no sense to you; buy Brink, play through the campaign and move out from that rock you have clearly been living under.

Spent 30 minutes being trolled by a drunk young kid walking around challenging everyone to a '♥♥♥♥ battle'. Even worse, it was in Stephen Hawking's voice. This kid was my mark for this particular mission, but since he wasn't interested in participating, we couldn't finish the game (it seems it's only over when everyone's main objective is complete and the story comes together, I think). Exiting the game is disabled during the duration of the scenario. Someone eventually Alt-F4ed out, which means the scenario couldn't have been completed even without Young Cheezy over there bothering everyone.  The other players were trying to figure the game out, but all in all it felt very awkward. Not sure if it was because I'm an introvert (and was already wanting to leave after the first 10 minutes of trying to socialize, either way), or because I couldn't really get into an acting/RPing mindset, or maybe a little of both. Tried engaging a couple people in conversation, trying to hide my character's 'true identity' and find out their roles, but no conversation ever really went past small talk. :-P  Highlight was when I 'did drugs' with someone -- which completed one of my secondary objectives, actually.    Novel idea for a game, regardless! I can't stress that enough! I loved the idea behind it!   Velvet Sundown would probably be an absolutely epic experience for the right audience (imaginitive RPers; mystery fans; theater buffs; etc.),  especially  among a group of friends.  Regardless, kudos to the devs! You get a Thumbs Up, even though it's not my thing. Your creativity shines through it all. :)  Keep up the good work!!!

Was a bit of an awkward game but worth trying out, especially because it is F2P. I like the concept of the game, being a multiplayer roleplaying game, but there is only one storyline you can do every week (at least that's how it seems). Each person is assigned a character and given missions to complete by trading and talking to other people. Also the people playing it can be pretty funny.  It can be ruined by afk players and there aren't many options as to how to play. Needs significant improvement -laggy, not many options, only one storyline a week. Would not buy this game in its current condition, but luckily you don't have to.   I think it's worth playing once. I found it amusing (giving it a thumbs up because it is F2P)

This is the worst game you'll ever play. You owe it to yourself to experience it, preferably for free.   There is no gameplay. There are no options. There aren't even item models or shadows. There's you, the cruise ship, some vague, tedious story points, and four other random members of the human race. What follows is the equivalent of being stuck in an elevator for 35 minutes. A very beige elevator. With godawful muzak. Seriously, if you appreciate awful things even a third as much as me, you need to play this game.  Just, for the love of God, don't give it any money.

It's definitely a fun concept, and it can be a blast. However, it has the misfortune of having all of its enjoyability based on the players you're thrown into the game with. Additionally, the lack of content will eventually lead to utter boredom. Give it a shot anyway, because as the gaming community we should support any new concepts or ideas (no matter how poorly excecuted they may be).

Velvet Sundown is a social multiplayer role-playing game, taking place on a luxury yacht cruising the waters of a fictitious Caribbean state of Balbonia. Embark on a journey full of conspiracies, trickery and secrets where you can never tell a friend from foe.  The game can be great fun with your friends, or a right set of people. You embark on a journey through different characters and know their stories, roleplay as their character as come into the world of Velvet Sundown.  Sounds great, doesn't it? It is with good the right set of people, but with the wrong set of people, the game can be boring and dull.  One thing which I hate, is people go AFK, during the game. Which ruins it completey and again becomes duller then ever. Some people say they have been crashing alot, from all the time I played it, I haven't crashed once.   Another thing that upsets me is there is Premieum content (spelled incorrectly) there are 2 scenarios, Sea and Fire and Fathe r and son, Currently Sea and Fire is premieum and you have to pay and it only lasts for a month.   If you have social skills or like roleplay or even playing with your friends or other people, give this game a try. It's free.

I've never had this much fun writing 'rub rub rub' into chat. although most people seem to have left by about half way though the scenario, it can still be fun discussing just what you're willing to give someone in exchange for a slum-child.
Text to speech     10/10
It's an adventure game with emphasis on talking. Unfortunately for the game to work, people must talk to you. If you don't talk, the game is a walking simulator on board a ship with some music.

Disconnects, drops, no matchmaking, no real solid explanations of what to do and how to do it other than vaguely going around the cruise ship zapping people, it's just a bit of a mess altogether. I'm sure that in the closed beta and that with the right groups the game can be incredibly fun, but this isn't the closed beta and it is not the other thing I mentioned. I'm not going to bother with looking at the game types you have to pay for because I'm already not super impressed with the one free one we have and how it's set up.

Alright, to preface this, I don't hate this game. But I can't say I reccomend it. I'll get to that.  Velvet Sundown is the equivalent of throwing 4-11 people out of an airplane, then emptying a jigsaw puzzle out the side of the plane as well. To pull their parachutes, the skydivers have to solve the puzzle. But, twist, sometimes there's two puzzles. Or three. Or four. Any you have no idea what pieces are for what puzzle.  What Velvet Sundown ends up being is hours of just handing people drinks, or collecting passports, or following a guy around. Then, once in every few days, you get a perfect combination of role, scenario, objective, and character, and you wreck shop. You solve your puzzle and pull your ripcord, and laugh as the others paint the ground below you. Laugh your way right to the bank.  I think everyone should *TRY* Velvet Sundown, because it's free. You have nothing to lose from playing it for an afternoon, just so that you're knowledgable on the subject, because I can see these mechanics being devealoped into some beautiful stuff in the future.

This game is definitely a game where you make your own fun. You take the role of a character and you really pretend you are that character. Then you can work together or take advantage of the people around you. If you don't put in an effort and instead expect the game to be fun on its own, then you're probably not going to have a good time. This is not like most games.  You can't join a game and expect there to be an experience, and since this game's community has a problem with people joining only to be afk, which in this game is a seriously annoying problem, sometimes you'll have to play an entire 30 minute round with only a few people, which really ruins the entire round.   There are also a lot of small issues. Controls are a bit clunky, which is mostly fine, but still annoying. If you're playing the free version, you are limited to one scenario, which means you're missing out on a third of the game. I'm not sure if paying the subscription fee is worth it, unless you're really dedicated. I think they said they're going to rethink this, but I'm honestly not sure.  This is going to be a really strange comparison, but I'm going to compare the game a bit to DayZ. Most of the fun is from your experiences with the players. The world and tools alone aren't all that interesting, and if you just buy DayZ without having any idea what it's about, explore the world a bit, ignore everyone else, and die, then you're going to have a pretty miserable experience. Where games like DayZ shine is the golden moments like, I dunno, staying alive wounded in a cabin with your friend, desperately hoping that you won't get hurt and the stranger outside the window isn't there to kill you. Few games give you that experience.  The issue with Velvet Sundown is that experiences like that don't happen as often. My first round was destroyed because there was only two other players actually playing. There were three people afk, making playing the actual game impossible. My second round went better, but afk players still meant that the round didn't play out properly. My third game was amazing, where I played a doublecrossing thief who made money off of working together with an alliance, then backstabbing them in favour of a second alliance. It was a great experience, but I'm not sure if that was worth one and a half hour of waiting and hoping that the afk players would come back to life. I have 2 hours of gameplay in this game, and I've only played these three games.  I'm not recommending this game, because the average person browsing this page because they saw Cr1tikal or Giant Bomb or whatever playing this game is NOT going to enjoy this game. It's free, but I don't think this is worth it for you. You really need to put a bit of yourself into it to make a good experience, and that's not something people are used to.
It's funny because you say crazy s**t to what i first thought of as NPC's and really weird. I would recommend. BTW my favorite character is Linda.

Wow. I'm impressed! Velvet Sundown is great, but not without flaws. Yes, it is a free to play but one that is heavily DLC dependent. Only 1 scenario + tutorial is available for free players. However, the game rotates between scenarios every hour and a half - for those with time to burn! Think Sherlock Holmes, but with 4 human players as passengers - one of which is the murderer!! It was a lot of fun, which is why I am recommending this game.

I really don't know how to word this, but I guess I'll try my best.   This game...this game can be really fun, and it can be really BAD at the same time. Not a whole lot of people play this game anymore, and I'm guessing I know why. The idea is to work with or against your fellow players to figure out who-dun-it, or try to accomplish your character's goals whilst on the ship.   There are a lot of times you'll get lucky and you'll get some AMAZING people who role play and pretend they are their character. Playing the game as it's intended to be played. Those games are what makes me come back and play it again.   Then you have the little kids....ahhhh, kids. Ruining video games 1 curse worded mouth at a time. I can't tell you how many times I've joined a game and had someone spam letters at me, curse at me, pretty much bullying other people, racism across ALL races, spewing out garbage from their tiny little pea brain mouths. I've also had many join just so they can disconnect purposely the moment they get in the game. This tends to ruin the game, especially if they have an item on them that you need, or if you need to hand them an item to complete a goal of yours.   I also think the fact that when you win or lose, there really isn't much of a difference. You don't win anything like costumes or new characters. You don't even get a 'you win!' spammed across your screen. So, winning doesn't give you that 'YEAH!' feeling like other games do. I think that is why there are so many trolls on this game who can't keep their attention on the actual game. Then you also get a lot of people who try to cyber with you and use the game as a way to ERP. Gross.   Overall, I think it would be a great game if there was a way to weed out the kiddos from being able to get on, or even a report system to report people who purposely d/c or try and curse you out with every curse in the book. Maybe if it linked up to your actual steam account and banned you through steam, maybe that would fix the issue, but then again...there is already a lack of people as it is, I feel like if that happened then there would be even less.   PROS: It's fun when played as intended. Good little time waster, fun little rpg, strategy based game. Text to speech. Who doesn't love text to speech??  CONS: The lack of missions, having to pay to be able to play the other two missions when nobody plays anymore, the kids, the fact that when a player d/cs it ruins your game (they should make it so if someone leaves and has an item on them you should have some sort of 'D/c taser' that tases your items off their person. That way it doesn't snow ball and so people don't d/c shortly after that one person because, let's be honest, it always snowballs into that. =/ Did I mention the kids who play? Yeah...Let's not get me started on those guys.   Did I mention the kids that play? Oh, right. I did..........grrr.  If this game had more (enjoyable) people on it, or more people in general...and a report system...I'd say this game would be fun. I still play it, but I always find myself quitting the moment those little brats start popping out of the wood work so if we had the option to report I think I could safely say that I'd recommend this game to a friend. I believe as it stands right now, if a friend asked me about this game, I'd tell them to try it once but expect the worst from it even though it can be fun.  I always hate giving bad reviews, especially when I still continue to play the game with my friend, but I'd have to say that I give this game a 4/10 in its current game state. If everything I mentioned above was taken care of I could safely say this would be a 6 to a 8. But I can't give it anything higher than a 4 right now and I definitely have to say I wouldn't recommend it to a friend unless they asked about it. Even then, that'd be pushing it. Sorry =/

One of the best games I've ever played when people play it the way it should be. One of the worst when you play with a handful of trolls.   I definitely recommend this game due to how much fun it is when you're in a match with some good people. Although I had to laugh at a game I had the other night. There was one troll and unfortunately for us it was the guy who committed the murder. He was going around saying he 'killed the captain, end the game' yadayadada. Everyone just blew him off and decided to thoroughly investigate the evidence. We 'roleplayed' that the trolls character was suffering from sort of mental disability and we all reversed him by telling him we'll catch the 'real' killer. It was very entertaining.  Definitely check this game out (especially now that it's available for free) and you'll be surprised at how much fun you have improvising and roleplaying with some good people. :)  Jonoridge

I joined the game and registered, then realized this wasn't a very populated game. I joined a murder queue and tabbed out, coming back an hour later when the game had enough people to join, but it was definately worth it. We started off trading evidence and we had a whole group conversation where eveyrone spoke one at a time about their opinions. Thanks to the layout of the evidence, it just so happened that I was the only one that didn't have any evidence against them (And no, I wasn't the murderer) so I ended up being the Detective and piecing together the evidence. I had private conversations with everyone one at a time where they all gave their alibis. In the end, I had gave my vote on the murderer, and everyone else eventually began to side with me, and it turns out we were completely wrong. Regardless, we all had a quick laugh and an exchange of 'GG's in the post-game chat before leaving.  Never before have I seen such a friendly community.
10/10 would text to speech again
